body: Is there any output in `alacritty -v` or `alacritty -vvv` when the URL is launched?

That's a good question.  Nothing is logged to .xsession-errors; I have not tried launching alacritty with -v.  I will see if I can find a way to modify the script that launches the sessions that use alacritty to use -v and redirect output to a log.
(I've tried to reproduce it in an alacritty launched from an xterm, but so far haven't been able to, as it seems to occur randomly and is not consistently reproducible.)

I'd expect this to be the recently added URL launching feature. It's currently still got a couple of issues and URLs aren't highlighted. So I'd try to disable that in the config and that should fix the problem, of course you won't be able to open URLs by clicking on them anymore either. But that's likely what's going on.
Well, it only occasionally mislaunches, so I don't want to disable it.  But I figured I should report the issue.

@UnixRonin I believe right now any mouse click will launch URLs, so that's probably what you're experiencing.

I'm gonna rename this issue to track what's going on.
Aaaaaaah!  That would certainly explain the behavior (though not why I had such difficulty trying to deliberately reproduce it).
Just jumping in here to suggest that middle mouse click be a copy of the URL, since that's somewhat consistent with Linux copy paste at least.
Middle mouse click is used for pasting, not for copying.

I've gained some additional information on this bug.  Sometimes alacritty will also launch the last URL it saw the user interact with in response to middle-button-pasting text that **IS NOT** a URL into the window.

I imagine the "launch only on left-click" enhancement would fix this part of the problem as well, but it possibly suggests some "leakage" somewhere.

issue.title: Improve URL detection
issue.body:
Since the initial version of URL detection had some issues with being a
bit over-eager to mark things as URLs, a different approach has been
taken instead.

To make parsing easier, instead of trying to detect the URL by using a
streaming parser to the left and right of the click position, the
complete buffer is now converted to a string and then searched for
links.

With this change, it was made possible to use the `linkify` library
which handles locating the URLs in the terminal buffer text. Since it
now automatically finds all present URLs, this also brings us a step
closer to #1618.

Fixes #1903.
Fixes #1753.
Fixes #1727.
